body:
Well, what are you trying to do with the data? A `TempFile` is to be used when you're trying to save the data to disk, or when the amount of data might exceed what you can store in memory. Given that you read the entire contents of the file into memory, your code is either wrong, you're accepting the crash due to memory exhaustion, or you're properly limiting file size.

If you're doing the latter, then indeed this is inefficient. Unfortunately Rocket doesn't and can't have `Vec<u8>` mean "a byte buffer" because `Vec<u8>` already means "a sequence of 8-bit unsigned integers," as far as forms go. We could add a `Bytes` or `Buffer` type or similar with the intended meaning, however.

If you're doing some sort of cheap computation with the data, then you probably don't want to buffer it all beyond, say, 4k streaming chunks, and store only the computed value. This is relatively easy to implement in Rocket via the `FromFormField` trait and gives you complete control over data limiting, buffering, and streaming.

> Well, what are you trying to do with the data? A `TempFile` is to be used when you're trying to save the data to disk, or when the amount of data might exceed what you can store in memory. Given that you read the entire contents of the file into memory, your code is either wrong, you're accepting the crash due to memory exhaustion, or you're properly limiting file size.
> 
> If you're doing the latter, then indeed this is inefficient. Unfortunately Rocket doesn't and can't have `Vec<u8>` mean "a byte buffer" because `Vec<u8>` already means "a sequence of 8-bit unsigned integers," as far as forms go. We could add a `Bytes` or `Buffer` type or similar with the intended meaning, however.
> 
> If you're doing some sort of cheap computation with the data, then you probably don't want to buffer it all beyond, say, 4k streaming chunks, and store only the computed value. This is relatively easy to implement in Rocket via the `FromFormField` trait and gives you complete control over data limiting, buffering, and streaming.

Yes I limit file sizes when configuring rocket.

A Bytes or Buffer type would be nice to have instead of manually implementing FromFormField. Sometimes you need the full file (small file) in memory.

Alternatively, I think it would be better (well more ergonomic) if TempFile or some alternative struct is guaranteed to be already in a file so that path() always return a file path. Or It could have some read methods which work whether it is buffered or in file?

i'll profit this issue to ask if it is possible to allow creation of the TempFile instance outside the `data` instance ? 

Some kind of multipart requests can allow multiple files in the `multipart/form-data` content, like how it's done in many graphQL clients using [this unofficial but commonly used spec](https://github.com/jaydenseric/graphql-multipart-request-spec).

The current `TempFile` processing sticks to the idea the provided body data is the file while in the previously mentionned case the file is one of the boundaries of the body data, not the whole one. 
 
I've wrote [some kind of prototype](https://github.com/Asone/juniper-rocket-multipart) to handle the above mentioned case with the spec, however i had to build a custom - and simplified - [TempFile](https://github.com/Asone/juniper-rocket-multipart/blob/master/src/temp_file.rs) struct, but i must admit that my knowledge of how to deal properly with buffered data is still quite limited and i would feel way more comfortable on being able to delegate this task to the framework. 

Do you think that having a method that would allow to build up TempFiles detached from the data body would be feasible ?

@Asone That's just a multipart form, which Rocket already [handles natively](https://rocket.rs/v0.5-rc/guide/requests/#multipart). Just use `TempFile` as a field of a struct that implements `FromForm`.

Okay, so here's my usecase. I want to hash a tempfile (preferably without writing it to disk at all), look up the hash in a database and finally persist the file if it's hash wasn't found.
Right now I have to
1. Write file to disk
2. Read it back
3. Hash it
4. Move it to a permanent location or delete

This feels unnecessarily complicated.

> @Asone That's just a multipart form, which Rocket already [handles natively](https://rocket.rs/v0.5-rc/guide/requests/#multipart). Just use `TempFile` as a field of a struct that implements `FromForm`.

The spec is a bit peculiar in my opinion as there is no way to know in advance all the fields that will be provided aside of the `operations` and `map` field. 

The submitted form could be : 

```
{
 operations : <Json Object>,
 map: <Json Object>,
 0: binary,
 1: binary
}
```

as 

```
{
 operations : <Json Object>,
 map: <Json Object>,
 a: binary,
 b: binary 
 c : binary,
 0 : binary,
 anything: binary
}
```

This seems incompatible with the `fromForm`, which is why i wrote the previously mentioned prototype, as it processes all the boundaries provided acknowledging that we cant know how many there'll be in advance and what there key name will be. 

But maybe i'm missing some subtleties with rust structs that would make it feasible or compatible with fromForm ? ðŸ¤· If so, i haven't found yet :/

> This feels unnecessarily complicated.

~~Not to mention that it doesn't work: persisting or copying for some reason silently fails, producing no file or error.~~

`FromForm` can handle any arbitrary structure at all. You never need to implement your own multipart parser. For instance, the `HashMap` type can collect all fields of a given type, irrespective of their field name.

I suggest a thorough reading of the FromForm and Form docs.

> We could add a Bytes or Buffer type or similar with the intended meaning, however.

I think this makes a lot of sense. I'm in agreement with other folks here that it would be advantageous to have access to that multipart data as a buffer of some kind. It's useful in some cases to store that data in memory rather than saving a temporary file, similar to Node.js `Buffer`s, which can be used to store the multipart data in memory.

I'll have a spin at an implementation of this over the weekend, any pointers/guidance on how this might be done would be helpful since it would be my first contribution to this project.

issue.title: Implement futures::stream::Stream on TempFile
issue.body:
**Is your feature request motivated by a concrete problem? Please describe.**
When you receive a TempFile, you can do almost nothing with it. Very often you do actually want to read the file you've received and sent it somewhere else, but the current API forces you to persist it to somewhere if you want to read it. 

**Why this feature can't or shouldn't live outside of Rocket**
Because TempFile is a type owned by rocket, you can't implement Stream on it without being rocket, and you also probably don't want to persist the file to then read it again, which you should do unless you want to rely on the #[doc(hidden)] elements of the enum. 

**Ideal Solution**
Implement Stream on TempFile so people can read it and stream it places to their heart's content.

**Alternatives Considered**
You could have an async method that returns a Vec<u8> of the file's contents, but this forces the contents of the entire file to go into memory.
You could also add another type like `Buffer` that just holds the entire file in memory.

**Additional Context**
This helps #2148 and doesn't require another type for being a buffer, and doesn't buffer the entire file in memory.

body:
Hello! 
Is there any method to keep the file in the multipart into the memory directly without dumping the file into the tempfile now?

Very thanks for any response!

issue.title: Support of &[u8] for form fields
issue.body:
Will allow to define forms with &[u8] fields, like
```rust
#[derive(FromForm)]
struct MyForm<'r> {
    foo: &'r [u8],
}
```

Should address the issue https://github.com/SergioBenitez/Rocket/issues/2148

body:
Do you guys think this change will suffice?
https://github.com/SergioBenitez/Rocket/pull/2361

issue.title: Add Bytes DataGuard
issue.body:
This will hopefully be sufficient for most of those concerned with issue #2148.
I might have gone the route of #2361 (implementing for `&[u8]`), but some people may want to get the filename and content-type as well, though I think that PR is still nice to have if all you need is the data.

body: @badoken Is it possible to make `&[u8]` work for the FromData trait as well? You can implement `FromFormField::from_value` by calling `field.value.as_bytes()`, which can be helpful if a content-type isn't supplied or the source is a query parameter.
